instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CHGR_CSO_N: What is CHGR_CSO_N? CHGR_CSO_N is one of the current sense lines for the battery. Resistance between CHGR_CSO_N and CHGR_CSO_P should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 2.2 ohms.
definitions.CHGR_CSO_P: What is CHGR_CSO_P? CHGR_CSO_P is one of the current sense lines for the battery. Resistance between CHGR_CSO_P and CHGR_CSO_N should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 2.2 ohms.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message:
just need some confirmation that my brain is working correctly here please. 
<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> had very minor liquid damaged. Cleaned and still can't get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. So no light on charger. After repairing <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> the charger is very dim for a second only. 
So I tested for shorts on ppbus g3h. Can't find any. 
Have traced it back to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_P</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_N</SIGNAL> are non existent.

So I have come to the conclusion that <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is dead. Have I missed any checks? Thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message: PPBUS has nothing to do with the green light. Only PP3V42. Bad IO board/cable are more likely when 3V42 is present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message:
I swear to god no matter how hard or how long I've been trying I cannot make sense of bloody schematics. It's drives me crazy. Great with hands fkn dumb dumb in my head. Really really wish I was in the states and could go sit with Louis or Jessa for however bloody long it takes..

Anyway can I ask this then. At L7095 or even <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR> I should be able to find me PP3V42. But I can't. I see 1.2v only.

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is getting 16v on pin 6 VIN.
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> is showing 16v pin 2 and pin 3. Pin 1 is under 1v but that's because there is no battery??? (Praying I read that right)..

so what im asking is could <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> be the culprit then?

Thanks duke. Any other subtle pointers you have would be highly appreciated!
Thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message: If there is only 1.2V on L7095 then there are 2 options. There is a low resistance/short on PP3V42 bus or <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is dead. The short is the most common, what is resistance to GND on PP3V42?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message:
PP3V42 shows 0.327 
L7095 shows 0.327 both sides 

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is dead then? It was the only water damaged part I could find anyway

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message: Diode mode. Negative on line positive on ground

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message: Need resistance to GND not diode mode.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message:
ok so I measured in ohms on the multimeter, 0.588 pp3v42

is that a correct way to measure? I'm not sure if I have the range set correctly either

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message: 0.588 Ohm seems unlikely as the diode mode measurement is usually lower in that case. Get some resistors of a known value and learn how a multimeter works.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message: lol thanks, believe me when I say I am trying!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no g3h
threads.message: Fixed! <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR>, replaced and charging and back on!
